content: >http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7971128.stm >http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8019966.stm Hitting 'em where they're not', the Pakistan Army has opened another offensive designed to restore central government power to one of the northwest provinces. Again. This, after a triple blast from US commanders accusing Pakistani intelligence of being behind virtually everything west of India and shy of Persia. Pakistan has been trying to subdue the northwest 'clans', one way or another, since the days it supported Anti-Soviet operations for the US. The Taliban were one of the early off-shoots of the kill Russians program. They've never gone away and have turned to bite the hands that fed them numerous times. There is always a chance that this time will be a kismet and see the northwest frontier become more pacific. The greater odds are that it will fail, again, and weaken one of the only friendly administrations America has left in the sub-continent. This message has been edited. Last edited by: popsiq, Mon 27 April 2009 06:37 PM
reply: >http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7971128.stm >http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8019966.stm Hitting 'em where they're not', the Pakistan Army has opened another offensive designed to restore central government power to one of the northwest provinces. Pakistan has been trying to subdue the northwest 'clans', one way or another, since the days it supported Anti-Soviet operations for the US. The Taliban were one of the early off-shoots of the kill Russians program. They've never gone away and have turned to bite the hands that fed them numerous times. There is always a chance that this time will be a kismet and see the northwest frontier become more pacific. The greater odds are that it will fail, again, and weaken one of the only friendly administrations America has left in the sub-continent. This message has been edited. Last edited by: popsiq, Mon 27 April 2009 06:37 PM
title: Pak Army Offensive Jeopardises Taliban Peace

content: To he11 with the Taliban and their azz-backwards religious extremism - we could kill every last one of them off and very few Americans would feel any remorse.

Kind of peculiar title for the thread: "Pak Army Offensive Jeopardises Taliban Peace" They've broken every agreement they signed with the government, and did so in hours of signing them. Dave Agreed, I think Pakistan is finally realizing they are on the hit list next and finally trying to do something. Part of the problem is they both have the same weapons and technology. Todays politics remind me of an old saying. - "Ideas are more powerful than guns. We would not let our enemies have guns, why should we let them have ideas?" - Joseph Stalin

content: quote: Originally posted by Ol_Doc: It's not often the three of us agree, but there it is. quote: Originally posted by Ol_Doc: This is an extremely dangerous situation the rest of the world had damn well keep a close eye on. What in hell was Pakistan thinking? They thought by giving the Taliban near autonomy in one provence they'd stop there?...roflmao And with their secret Police semi-controlling their army? And with all the WMD's they have, that no one seemed to mind them getting? Were the Paki's thinking that these agreements bought them time? Bought them about a half hour per argremeent... How many were there anyway? Half a dozen? More? Mean while Karzai and company are talking about making agreements with THEIR Taliban. Talk about history repeating itself! Dave
quote: Originally posted by Ol_Doc: It's not often the three of us agree, but there it is.
